What is linear algebra?
Before jumping into the main material of the course, we first ask the basic question: what is (note: why can't I get italics or bold to work here?) linear algebra?
There are two main answers to this question which we would like to offer now. In particular, we can describe what the study of linear algebra is all about by saying what the "objects" it studies are, and by what the applications of the main results are.
All of mathematics is calculus and linear algebra.
(How do I put quotes around a theorem?)
Linear algebra is the study of "flat" things; for example, lines (as implied by the name) and planes. If everything in the world were flat, and if objects always moved in a straight line at a constant speed, then geometry and physics would just be linear algebra. Of course, real life is curvy, and sometimes moving objects do change directions or speed. However, like the Earth looks flat to us, everything curved locally looks flat. Using calculus, we can approximate curvy things by flat things (using linear approximation), which are then in the domain of linear algebra.
